repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Second School Improvement
            (FUNDESCOLA II) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Brazil Second School Improvement
            Project had a successful outcome, its sustainability is
            highly likely, with substantial institutional development
            impact, and both Bank and Borrower performances were
            satisfactory. Important lessons cited from this project
            concerned: Long-term Bank support for well-defined national
            education programs; recognition of the role of the different
            levels of Government; seeking strategies to mobilize
            support, generate local demand, and ensure sustainability;
            balancing hiring external implementation agencies and
            consultants with building Borrower's institutional
            capacity; and the importance of establishing a strong
            control framework with clear and transparent institutional
            and implementation arrangements during project preparation
            to avoid reliance of external agencies for project implementation.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Second School Improvement Project
            (FUNDESCOLA II)

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second School Improvement Project
            (FUNDESCOLA II) for Brazil is the second in a series of
            projects designed to improve the performance of public
            primary education in selected areas of the North, Northeast,
            and Center-West regions. There are five components. The
            first raises schools to minimum operational standards by
            funding minor school repair and purchasing supplies,
            instructional material, and equipment; training and
            certifying teachers for distance learning programs,
            supplying basic furniture, renovating schools, and
            constructing new model primary schools. The second component
            designs and implements school development plans, finances
            school improvement projects, and develops, tests, and
            implements pedagogic models. The third component promotes
            communication and social mobilization by disseminating
            strategy and results and building a network of social
            communicators. The fourth component improves national
            assessment and integrates national and international best
            practice, supports an integrated education information
            system and a school census, and develops evaluation studies
            and educational research. The fifth component strengthens
            state and municipal collaboration, develops new management
            models for state and municipal educational secretariats, and
            develops surveys and a geographic information database.
